results.title: Possums of Bonegilla
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Agnes Karlik
results.brief_description: Agnes talks of her migrant experience including her time spent at Bonegilla. She especially focuses on friendships made during those early years of alienation and loneliness.

results.title: Hand painted strip slide magic lantern with chimney
results.brief_description:
Hand painted strip slide magic lantern projector with chimney, and one set of hand painted glass slides (in restored condition).
Strip slide is a single sheet of glass with hand painting directly on to glass. Slide has a wooden frame (stable condition)
1 x Box containing projector
1 x Package containing glass slide (VERY FRAGILE)

results.title: Always a farmer
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Against the Grain” in association with Partners in Grain (PING).
Not just a farmer’s wife, Jenny Grigg, mother of four and business partner in all ways with her husband on their Mallee sheep and grain farm discovered a group of women who were to change Jenny’s life forever.
This story is dedicated to that network of women (PinG) who help and support other farming women in grains by providing inspiration and encouragement and a feeling of self-worth.

group.title: Against the grain: digital storytelling project

results.title: The Blinds and the Shutters
results.brief_description: This work presents a virtual world comprised of a modernist fictional house in a remote forest setting, whose contents gradually spill and float out of every aperture. Shoes and dresses, pots and pans, cutlery, pillows, blankets and plates journey in two directions simultaneously, some disappearing into the distance never to return, others appearing across all four screens in the installation. The larger objects fade up like apparitions, disappear and then reappear in strange locations, breaking all logic that is guiding this imaginary world. The slow drift of these household objects around the four screens is uncanny. While their journey suggests that the natural phenomenon of air is present, there is also a sense of airlessness; a claustrophobic, almost heavily scented environment. Despite sharing an energy force within the virtual environment, these objects are estranged – for they have lost their domestic relationship with one another. The sounds of bumps, collisions and muffled shuffles emerging from the interior of the house underscores the mystery of this scene. The disturbing atmosphere is most bizarre when the household goods are propelled into outer space, taking on the form of miniature satellites presumably tracking our behaviour from afar.

results.title: Blood
results.brief_description:
Travelling through Australia with his film camera, Ivan Sen has visited many Aboriginal communities, from urban to prison to distant-rural. Photographing people in their definitive environments, he has created an installation which is a subtle and deeply moving meditation on skin, landscape, gesture and the many nuances of Aboriginal identities.

The work contains imagery of people who have all shared the same blood. The blood of the Gamilaroi people of Northern NSW.

results.title: Cyberdelia
results.credit_line:
Steve Spangaro, director
Mike Collins, associate director
Milena Romanin, production manager
Susan King, interviews and research
Based on an original concept by Adem Jaffers
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
Cyberdelia is a visceral encounter with the aesthetic and ideals of Melbourne underground cyber artists at the confluence of analogue and digital creative practice in 1991.

In blending artist interviews and works, this magazine style documentary explores visions of personal and cultural enhancement through transformative digital technologies. The imminent fusion of spirituality with technology; flesh with machine and psychedelia with cybernetics is confidently proclaimed.

Cyberdelia is a visual and aural feast with the film-makers channelling the post-modern mischief and transcendental yearnings of the ‘cyberdelic’ movement to radical stylistic effect. Stunning cyber artist works are liberally leveraged as both feature material and interstitial fodder. Low-budget analogue video editing and compositing tools are pushed to the limit while artist on-camera interviews are staged in bizarre fashion so as to maintain the feel of a ‘trip documentary’ from start to finish.

Produced for broadcast on community television station RMITV, Cyberdelia stretches the boundaries of arts documentary to portray the brazen idealism and micro-processor powered creativity of these pre World Wide Web visionaries.

Artists: Acid Death Bed, Misha Hollenbach, Troy Innocent (Cyber Dada), Natalie Jeremijenko, Adem Jaffers (Neuro), Jeff Jaffers (Third Eye), Dale Nason (Cyber Dada), Ollie Olsen (Third Eye) Captain ROM, Stelarc, Gus Till (Third Eye), Julian Wong, Christopher Wright and Max Q.

Cyberdelia was generously donated to ACMI by Cyberdelia Productions.

results.title: Cyberthon VI: VAT
results.brief_description:
After the success of Spectrum, the Cyberthon artists were invited by Telstra to create a submission for an exhibition called The Edge, to be displayed at the Telstra Corporate Center on Exhibition Street. This demo was presented to Telstra at an annual meeting held at Dallas Brooks Hall.

The demo shows a CGI artists impression of the proposed ‘The Edge exhibition’ space as well as a simulation of the media submission process via the interactive Cyberthon VAT (V=Video, A=Audio, T=Text) porthole created using Deluxe Paint, with presentation edited in Scala on an Amiga 2000.

Animation loops that appear in simulated submission section were created by Ian Haig, Cyber Dada (Troy Innocent and Dale Nason), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton & Attillio Gangemi), Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Julian Wong, Mish Fingers (Misha Hollenbach), Derek Shiel, Martine Corompt, and Force Fed (Stuart McCormick). Video camera footage was shot by Dale Nason from the back of a Chris Wrights moving van. 35mm still photographs were taken by Tao Wiess. Audio track was mixed by DJ Visitor (Andrew Till).

This work is part of the Cyberthon Archive, generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 8 - Black & White
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon V: Spectrum 8 – Black and White was broadcast as the sixth of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!” In a first for Cyberthon, if not globally this episode was an interactive TV test pilot experiment. It allowed visitors to the Lounge Café, Melbourne an opportunity to compile sequences from the Cyberthon database from a computer also networked to RMITV studio.

A selection of artworks presented were created by: Ian Haig, Adem Jaffers, Dale Nason, Steve Middleton, Attillio Gangemi, Julian Wong, Misha Hollenbach, Derek Shiel, Martine Corompt, Stuart McCormick and DJ Andrew Till (The Visitor).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 8 – Black and White is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.
